sen.j: 吉見氏（よしみし）は武家の姓のひとつ。
sen.e: The Yoshimi clan was a samurai clan in Japan.
The Yoshimi clan was a samurai clan in Japan.
The Yoshimi clan was a samurai clan in Japan.

sen.j: 本姓は源氏。
sen.e: Their original family name was Ganji (Minamoto clan).
Their original family name was Ganji (Minamoto clan).
Their original family name was Ganji (Minamoto clan).

sen.j: 家系は清和源氏ひとつ河内源氏の棟梁源義朝の六男で、鎌倉幕府初代征夷大将軍源頼朝の庶弟にあたる三河守源範頼を祖とする。
sen.e: Their family lineage started from Mikawa no kami (Governor of Mikawa Province) MINAMOTO no Noriyori who was a step-brother of the first Seii Taishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) of Kamakura Shogunate MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, the sixth son of the head of Kawachi-Genji, which was a lineage of the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa), MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo.
sen.cmt: 「家系は清和源氏（の）ひとつ」と解釈しました。
sen.e: The family line started from Mikawa no kami (Governor of Mikawa Province) MINAMOTO no Noriyori, who was a step-brother of the first Seii Taishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) of Kamakura Shogunate MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, and the sixth son of the head of Kawachi-Genji, a branch family of the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa), MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo.

The family line started from Mikawa no kami (Governor of Mikawa Province) MINAMOTO no Noriyori, who was a step-brother of the first Seii Taishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) of Kamakura Shogunate MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, and the sixth son of the head of Kawachi-Genji, a branch family of the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa), MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo.

sen.j: 範頼は横見郡吉見郷を領して吉見御所と尊称されていた。
sen.e: Noriyori was respectively called 'Yoshimi Gosho' (the Emperor of Yoshimi) as Yoshimigo of Yoshimi District was his territory.
Noriyori was respected as the lord of Yoshimigo of Yoshimi District and called 'Yoshimi Gosho' (the Emperor of Yoshimi).
sen.cmt: respectivelyが尊敬をあらわすのは稀（タンダムハス英和大辞典）
sen.e: Noriyori was respected as the lord of Yoshimigo of Yoshimi District and called 'Yoshimi Gosho' (the Emperor of Yoshimi).

sen.j: 範頼は謀叛の疑いで伊豆の修善寺にて攻撃され自害するが、その次男の源範圓・三男源昭が外曾祖母 比企禅尼から、武蔵国横見郡吉見庄を分与された。
sen.e: Yorinori was suspected of organizing a rebellion and when he was attacked at the Shuzen-ji temple of Izu, he committed suicide; his second son MINAMOTO no Yorien and third son MINAMOTO no Akira were given the Yoshiminosho, Yoshimi District, Musashi Province from his maternal great-grandmother Hiki Zenni.
sen.cmt: 「源範圓」および「源昭」は読みが不明です。
sen.e: Although Yorinori committed suicide when attacked at the Shuzen-ji temple in Izu on suspicion of organizing a rebellion, Yoshiminosho, Yoshimi District, Musashi Province was distributed to his second son MINAMOTO no Yorien and third son MINAMOTO no Akira by their maternal great-grandmother Hiki Zenni.
sen.cmt: 表現変更「源範圓」および「源昭」は読み不明
sen.e: Although Yorinori committed suicide when attacked at the Shuzen-ji temple in Izu on suspicion of organizing a rebellion, Yoshiminosho, Yoshimi District, Musashi Province was distributed to his second son MINAMOTO no Yorien and third son MINAMOTO no Akira by their maternal great-grandmother Hiki Zenni.

sen.j: 範圓の子である為頼に至って吉見を名字とした。
sen.e: Yorien's son Tameyori chose 'Yoshimi' as his family name.
Yorien's son Tameyori chose 'Yoshimi' as his family name.
Yorien's son Tameyori chose 'Yoshimi' as his family name.

sen.j: 子孫は御家人として存続し吉見氏と称した。
sen.e: His descendants survived as Gokenin (shogunal retainers) and they all called themselves 'Yoshimi'.
His descendants survived as Gokenin (shogunal retainers) and they all called themselves 'Yoshimi'.
His descendants survived as Gokenin (shogunal retainers) and they all called themselves 'Yoshimi'.

sen.j: 子孫の一人である吉見頼行は能登吉見氏の庶家で、石見鹿足郡の地頭職を得て下向したものである。
sen.e: One of the descendants, Yoriyuki YOSHIMI was from a branch family of the Noto-Yoshimi clan and left the capital when he was appointed as a Jitoshiki (manager and lord of an estate) of Kanoashi District, Iwami Province.

One of the descendants, Yoriyuki YOSHIMI was from a branch family of the Noto-Yoshimi clan and left the capital when he was appointed as a Jitoshiki (manager and lord of an estate) of Kanoashi District, Iwami Province.

One of the descendants, Yoriyuki YOSHIMI was from a branch family of the Noto-Yoshimi clan and left the capital when he was appointed as a Jitoshiki (manager and lord of an estate) of Kanoashi District, Iwami Province.

sen.j: 石見吉見氏は木部・津和野・吉賀地方の在地領主を被官化しつつ次第に勢力を拡張し、隣接する強豪益田氏と拮抗する有力領主に成長した。
sen.e: The Iwami-Yoshimi clan expanded their power while vassalizing local lords of Kibe, Tsuwano and Yoshika regions and became an influential lord opposite their powerful neighbor the Masuda clan.

The Iwami-Yoshimi clan expanded its power by putting local lords under its control in Kibe, Tsuwano and Yoshika regions, developing into an influential lord equally matching in strength with the Masuda clan, a powerful lord in neighboring regions.

The Iwami-Yoshimi clan expanded its power by putting local lords under its control in Kibe, Tsuwano and Yoshika regions, developing into an influential lord equally matching in strength with the Masuda clan, a powerful lord in neighboring regions.

sen.j: 戦国時代には大内氏・毛利氏の影響下におかれ、江戸時代には毛利氏の家臣として組み込まれたがまもなく粛清された。
sen.e: During the Sengoku period (the Warring States period), they were under the influence of Ouchi and Mori clans and in the Edo period, they became vassals of the Mori clan but soon were purged.
During the Sengoku period (the Warring States period), the clan was under the influence of Ouchi and Mori clans, and in the Edo period, it was purged soon after it became vassals of the Mori clan.
During the Sengoku period (the Warring States period), the clan was under the influence of Ouchi and Mori clans, and in the Edo period, it was purged soon after it became vassals of the Mori clan.

tit.j: 吉見氏嫡流の隆盛と衰亡
tit.e: The Rise and Fall of the Direct Descendants of the Yoshimi Clan
The Rise and Fall of the Direct Descendants of the Yoshimi Clan
The Rise and Fall of the Direct Descendants of the Yoshimi Clan

sen.j: 頼朝は平家の滅亡後、源氏一門の多くを謀叛の罪として処刑し、吉見氏の祖である範頼もその例に漏れなかったが、子孫は源氏の名門として存続。
sen.e: After the destruction of the Heike, Yoritomo executed many members of the Minamoto family for the sin of rebellion and the ancestor of the Yoshimi clan Noriyori could not avoid this fate but his descendants survived as a pedigree family of a Minamoto clan.

After the fall of the Heike family, Yoritomo executed many members of the Minamoto families on charge of rebellion including Noriyori, the first head of the Yoshimi clan, but Noriyori's descendants managed to survive as a distinguished family of the Minamoto clan.

After the fall of the Heike family, Yoritomo executed many members of the Minamoto families on charge of rebellion including Noriyori, the first head of the Yoshimi clan, but Noriyori's descendants managed to survive as a distinguished family of the Minamoto clan.

sen.j: 執権北条氏が幕府の実権を握った後も命脈を保っていた。
sen.e: They kept their thread of lineage even after the Regent Hojo clan took over the real power of the Shogunate.
The clan kept surviving after the Regent Hojo clan took over power of the Shogunate.
The clan kept surviving after the Regent Hojo clan took over power of the Shogunate.

sen.j: しかし、北条氏が武蔵国の在地勢力を冷遇したためか、為頼三代の子孫吉見義世は謀叛をたくらみ事前に発覚したため、処刑される。
sen.e: However, the Hojo clan might have treated local authority of the Musashi Province unkindly, the third generation of Tameyori's descendant Yoshiyo YOSHIMI organized a rebellion but the plot was found and he was executed.

However, Yoshiyo YOSHIMI, the third generation of Tameyori, plotted to overthrow the Hojo clan probably because of Hojo clan's cold treatment of local powers, and he was executed after the plot came to light.

However, Yoshiyo YOSHIMI, the third generation of Tameyori, plotted to overthrow the Hojo clan probably because of Hojo clan's cold treatment of local powers, and he was executed after the plot came to light.

sen.j: その弟らも義世の与党として流刑となったため、吉見氏嫡流の命脈は絶え、宗家の家督と武蔵国の所領は二代吉見義春の弟で能登国の住人となっていた吉見頼宗の子、即ち義春の甥である吉見頼隆の系統に引き継がれた。
sen.e: Yoshiyo's brothers were all exiled as Yoshiyo's ruling coalition and the lineage of the direct descendant of the Yoshimi clan came to an end; the estate of the head family and territories in the Musashi Province were handed to the family of the Noto Province resident Yoritaka YOSHIMI who was a son of Yoshimune YOSHIMI, a brother of the second generation Yoshiharu YOSHIMI (therefore a nephew of Yoshiharu).

Yoshiyo's brothers were all exiled on charge of a privy to Yoshiyo's plot, and the lineage of the direct descendant of the Yoshimi clan came to an end; the family headship and territories of Musashi Province were handed down to the family line of the Noto Province resident Yoritaka YOSHIMI who was a son of Yoshimune YOSHIMI, a brother of the second family head Yoshiharu YOSHIMI (therefore a nephew of Yoshiharu).

Yoshiyo's brothers were all exiled on charge of a privy to Yoshiyo's plot, and the lineage of the direct descendant of the Yoshimi clan came to an end; the family headship and territories of Musashi Province were handed down to the family line of the Noto Province resident Yoritaka YOSHIMI who was a son of Yoshimune YOSHIMI, a brother of the second family head Yoshiharu YOSHIMI (therefore a nephew of Yoshiharu).

sen.j: これらは能登吉見氏、武蔵吉見氏とよばれる。
sen.e: These clans were called Noto-Yoshimi and Musashi-Yoshimi.
These clans were called Noto-Yoshimi and Musashi-Yoshimi.
These clans were called Noto-Yoshimi and Musashi-Yoshimi.

sen.j: 石見吉見氏は源範圓の庶子の系統だが、頼円に至るまでの系譜は明らかでない。
sen.e: The Iwami-Yoshimi clan was the lineage of the illegitimate child of MINAMOTO no Yorien but the family tree up to Raien is not clear.
The Iwami-Yoshimi clan is a family line of a illegitimate child of MINAMOTO no Yorien, but its family tree before Raien's generation is not known.
The Iwami-Yoshimi clan is a family line of a illegitimate child of MINAMOTO no Yorien, but its family tree before Raien's generation is not known.

sen.j: 吉見氏は後醍醐天皇の挙兵に際し、朝廷方について戦った。
sen.e: The Yoshimi clan fought for the Imperial Court when the Emperor Godaigo raised his army.
The Yoshimi clan fought on the side of the Imperial Court when the Emperor Godaigo raised his army.
The Yoshimi clan fought on the side of the Imperial Court when the Emperor Godaigo raised his army.

sen.j: この時の家督は吉見頼直であったと思われる。
sen.e: The head of the family at that time is believed to be Yorinao YOSHIMI.
sen.cmt: 「吉見頼直」の読みが不明です。
sen.e: The head of the family at that time is believed to be Yorinao YOSHIMI.
The head of the family at that time is believed to be Yorinao YOSHIMI.

sen.j: しかし、後醍醐天皇と足利尊氏との間に亀裂が生じ、南北朝時代 (日本)に入ると吉見頼直は北朝・足利方につき、備後国の国人に兵を送る様に要請したところから、源氏の一門として、一定の地位にあったのではないかといわれる。
sen.e: However, when a rift began to appear in the relationship between the Emperor Godaigo and Takauji ASHIKAGA and when the period of the Northern and Southern Courts started, Yoshinao YOSHIMI sided with the Northern Court Ashikaga clan and ordered a dispatch of troops to the local samurai of the Bingo Province; this is the reason why he is believed to have been in a higher position as a Minamoto clan.

However, when a rift in the relationship between the Emperor Godaigo and Takauji ASHIKAGA developed into the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), Yoshinao YOSHIMI sided with the Northern Court Ashikaga clan and ordered kokujin (local lords) of the Bingo Province to dispatch their troops; this is the reason why he is believed to have been in a higher position as a Minamoto clan.

However, when a rift in the relationship between the Emperor Godaigo and Takauji ASHIKAGA developed into the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), Yoshinao YOSHIMI sided with the Northern Court Ashikaga clan and ordered kokujin (local lords) of the Bingo Province to dispatch their troops; this is the reason why he is believed to have been in a higher position as a Minamoto clan.

sen.j: 代々、石見国津和野を領して益田氏とともに石見国の二大国人として名を馳せた。
sen.e: For generations, having their territory in Tsuwano, Iwami Province, the clan was one of the two most powerful clans in the Iwami Province together with the Masuda clan.
For generations, the clan kept their territory in Tsuwano, Iwami Province and was known as one of the two most powerful kokujin in the Province together with the Masuda clan.
For generations, the clan kept their territory in Tsuwano, Iwami Province and was known as one of the two most powerful kokujin in the Province together with the Masuda clan.

sen.j: 吉見頼興は足利義稙と足利義澄による家督争いにおいては義稙方である大内義興に従い、京都船岡山合戦において活躍した。
sen.e: At the fight over the status of the head of the family between Yoshitane ASHIKAGA and Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA, Yorinori YOSHIMI followed Yoshioki OUCHI and fought hard at the Battle of Funaokayama, Kyoto.
At the fight over the status of the head of the family between Yoshitane ASHIKAGA and Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA, Yorinori YOSHIMI followed Yoshioki OUCHI and fought hard at the Battle of Funaokayama, Kyoto.
At the fight over the status of the head of the family between Yoshitane ASHIKAGA and Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA, Yorinori YOSHIMI followed Yoshioki OUCHI and fought hard at the Battle of Funaokayama, Kyoto.

sen.j: しかし、戦国時代 (日本)における吉見氏の中で最も著名なのは頼興の子である吉見正頼・吉見広頼親子であろう。
sen.e: However, the most famous members of the clan in the Sengoku period were the father-and-son pair, Yorioki's son Masayori YOSHIMI and Hiroyori YOSHIMI.
However, the most famous members of the clan in the Sengoku period (Japan) were the father-and-son pair, Yorioki's son Masayori YOSHIMI and Hiroyori YOSHIMI.
However, the most famous members of the clan in the Sengoku period (Japan) were the father-and-son pair, Yorioki's son Masayori YOSHIMI and Hiroyori YOSHIMI.

sen.j: 吉見氏としては庶流の系統であるが、有力国人として大内義興の娘婿となる。
sen.e: They were from a branch family of the Yoshino clan but as a powerful local samurai, Masayori became an adopted son-in-law of Yoshioki OUCHI.
Being from a branch family of the Yoshimi clan, they were regarded as a powerful kokujin and Masayori became an adopted son-in-law of Yoshioki OUCHI.
Being from a branch family of the Yoshimi clan, they were regarded as a powerful kokujin and Masayori became an adopted son-in-law of Yoshioki OUCHI.

sen.j: その関係もあり、大内義隆が守護代陶隆房の謀叛によって死亡し、大内氏を大内義長が継ぐと、これに反発して反陶の兵を挙げ、陶軍と戦っている。
sen.e: For this, when Yoshitaka OUCHI was killed in the rebellion by Shugodai (deputy military governor) Takafusa SUE and Yoshinaga OUCHI succeeded, Masayori fought against the Sue's army after raising his own army.

For this son-in-law-relationship, when Yoshitaka OUCHI was killed in the rebellion by Shugodai (deputy military governor) Takafusa SUE and replaced by Yoshinaga OUCHI as head of Ouchi family, Masayori raised his own army to fight against the Sue's army.

For this son-in-law-relationship, when Yoshitaka OUCHI was killed in the rebellion by Shugodai (deputy military governor) Takafusa SUE and replaced by Yoshinaga OUCHI as head of Ouchi family, Masayori raised his own army to fight against the Sue's army.

sen.j: その後、毛利氏に従ったが、江戸時代初めに謀反の疑いで当主の吉見広長が誅殺された。
sen.e: Later on, he worked under the Mori clan but the family head Hironaga YOSHIMI was killed in the early Edo period for suspicion of plotting a rebellion.
Later on, the Yoshimi clan had worked under the Mori clan until the family head Hironaga YOSHIMI was killed in the early Edo period for suspicion of plotting a rebellion.
Later on, the Yoshimi clan had worked under the Mori clan until the family head Hironaga YOSHIMI was killed in the early Edo period for suspicion of plotting a rebellion.

sen.j: その後の吉見氏は吉川広家の子の毛利就頼が継承したが、やがて就頼は毛利姓に復し大野毛利家を興したため、吉見氏は断絶した。
sen.e: After that, Hiroie KIKKAWA's son Nariyori MORI succeeded the Yoshimi clan but Nariyori returned to the Mori family name to establish the Ono-Mori clan, the Yoshimi clan came to an end.

After this incident, Hiroie KIKKAWA's son Nariyori MORI succeeded the Yoshimi family, but Nariyori returned his family name to Mori and established the Ono-Mori clan, bringing the Yoshimi clan to an end.

After this incident, Hiroie KIKKAWA's son Nariyori MORI succeeded the Yoshimi family, but Nariyori returned his family name to Mori and established the Ono-Mori clan, bringing the Yoshimi clan to an end.
